etymologies: Old English templ, tempel, reinforced in Middle English by Old French temple, both from Latin templum ‘open or consecrated space’

definitions: a building for religious worship, especially in religions other than Christianity.

either of two successive religious buildings of the Jews in Jerusalem. The first (957–586 BC) was built by Solomon and destroyed by Nebuchadnezzar; it contained the Ark of the Covenant. The second (515 BC–AD 70) was enlarged by Herod the Great from 20 BC and destroyed by the Romans during a Jewish revolt; all that remains is the Wailing Wall.
shortDefinitions: either of two successive religious buildings of Jews in Jerusalem

definitions: a place of Christian public worship, especially a Protestant church in France.
a thing regarded as holy or likened to a temple, especially a person's body

examples.text: June treats her body like a temple: she takes yoga classes every day

definitions: a place devoted to or seen as the centre of a particular activity or interest
shortDefinitions: place devoted to or seen as centre of particular activity or interest

definitions: a group of buildings in Fleet Street, London, which stand on land formerly occupied by the headquarters of the Knights Templar. Located there are the Inner and Outer Temple, two of the Inns of Court.
shortDefinitions: group of buildings in Fleet Street, London

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French, from an alteration of Latin tempora, plural of tempus ‘temple of the head’

definitions: the flat part of either side of the head between the forehead and the ear

examples.text: a man with curly hair graying at the temples

shortDefinitions: flat part of either side of head between forehead and ear

etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, perhaps ultimately the same word as temple

definitions: a device in a loom for keeping the cloth stretched.
shortDefinitions: device in loom for keeping cloth stretched
